unnormalised: India, with its rich biodiversity, is a real hotspot for wildlife. From the snow leopards of the Himalayas to the colourful birds of the Western Ghats, we've got a lot to lose. Think about the majestic Bengal tiger – a national symbol, but sadly, also endangered. Organizations like the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) are doing amazing research and training to help conserve them.

unnormalised: Why is this so crucial? Well, biodiversity is what keeps our ecosystems healthy and functioning. Losing species disrupts this balance, affecting everything from pollination (essential for agriculture!) to water purification. It’s all interconnected, like the spices in a really good biryani – you take one out, and the whole thing is just…off.

unnormalised: Habitat loss is a HUGE problem. As cities expand and forests are cleared for agriculture (think sugarcane farming), animals lose their homes and are forced into closer contact with humans, leading to conflict. Poaching, driven by the illegal wildlife trade (especially for things like rhino horns, sold for lakhs of Rupees!), is another major threat.

unnormalised: So, what can we do? A lot, actually! Supporting conservation organizations like WWF-India is a great start. We can also be more mindful of our consumption habits, reducing our demand for products that contribute to deforestation. Educating ourselves and others is key too. Simple things like avoiding single-use plastics can make a difference to marine life. And when you travel, choose eco-friendly tourism options that support local communities and conservation efforts.
